logs.title: Bloatnet Initiative Planning Started
logs.description: Initial collaboration between Nethermind and Ethereum Foundation teams to explore artificial state growth and establish testing goals for 2x mainnet state.
details: CPerezz, Kamil Chodoła, and Marcin scheduled initial meeting
Goal established: achieve artificial state growth of at least 2x mainnet
Partnership formed with EF DevOps and Geth teams
logs.author: Bloatnet Team

logs.title: Geth Bloating Tool Development
logs.description: Guillaume (asqyzeron) developed specialized Geth fork capable of bloating state directly at block production, creating ~10k accounts per block with 15 million leaves.
details: Introduced BloatNetTime parameter in genesis.json
Creates uniform accounts with max 30 leaves each
Tool available at gballet/go-ethereum:bloat-per-block branch
Override flag --override.bloat added by jsvisa
logs.author: Guillaume (Geth Team)

logs.title: Critical Memory and RPC Issues Discovered
logs.description: Multiple critical issues discovered during bloating: extreme memory consumption, RPC bottlenecks at high gas limits, and network finality loss.
details: Geth consuming 60GB+ memory due to 128 trie layers in memory
RPC unable to handle 20-50k pending transactions at 500M gas limit
Mempool issues causing 0-tx blocks despite thousands pending
Network lost finality multiple times during heavy bloating
logs.author: jsvisa & CPerezz

logs.title: Spamoor Bloating Scenarios Deployed
logs.description: CPerezz deployed comprehensive state bloating scenarios via Spamoor, enabling systematic state growth through various attack vectors.
details: Contract deployment scenario for bytecode bloating
SetCodeTx scenario with 7702 auth abuse
EXTCODESIZE attack scenario implementation
Storage slot bloating optimized for state growth
logs.author: CPerezz

logs.title: Perf-devnet-2 Network Launched
logs.description: Public Bloatnet network successfully launched at perf-devnet-2.ethpandaops.io with multi-client support and comprehensive monitoring.
details: Dora block explorer deployed at dora.perf-devnet-2.ethpandaops.io
Grafana dashboards configured for all major clients
Support for Geth, Nethermind, Reth, Erigon, and Besu
Initial state size: 1.3TB (~1.5x mainnet)
logs.author: Pari (EthPandaOps)

logs.title: First Sync Performance Baselines
logs.description: Completed comprehensive sync tests across multiple clients with bloated state, establishing critical performance baselines at 1.5x mainnet size.
details: Nethermind: 36 minutes snap sync + 40 seconds healing phase
Erigon and Reth successfully synced to head
Peak DB reads: 600k ops/minute during sync
Peak DB writes: 400k ops/minute during sync
logs.author: Kamil Chodoła

logs.title: XEN Contract Bloating Scenario Added
logs.description: Philipp (pk910) implemented XEN contract replication scenario to create massive individual contract states for stress testing.
details: Replicates mainnet XEN contract attack patterns
Creates extremely large individual contract states
Scenario distribution: 50% SSTORE, 25% EIP7702, 25% XEN
Targeting ~600M gas per block
logs.author: Philipp (pk910)

logs.title: Critical Healing Phase Bug Found
logs.description: Discovered critical issue where Nethermind's healing phase gets stuck indefinitely under heavy load, preventing successful sync completion.
details: Node stuck in StateNodes sync phase for 12+ hours
Issue triggered at 800Mgas blocks with heavy state changes
Healing completed in 6 minutes after reducing load
Multiple DB corruptions observed on same machine
logs.author: Kamil Chodoła & Ben Adams

logs.title: Block Building Timeout Issues Identified
logs.description: Multiple clients experiencing block building timeouts at high gas limits, with Lighthouse having 2s timeout causing missed proposals.
details: Lighthouse 2s timeout too low for high gas blocks
Reth taking 2.1s+ for some blocks at 1000M gas
Besu producing empty blocks due to timeout issues
Spec requirement of 1s timeout proven unrealistic
logs.author: Pari & pk910

logs.title: Reached 1.5x Mainnet State Size
logs.description: Successfully bloated state to 750GB total, achieving approximately 1.5x mainnet state size with balanced growth ratios.
details: State composition: ~250GB storage, ~25GB accounts, ~30GB bytecode
Stable bloating achieved at 300M gas after reducing from 800M
Multiple stress points identified in various clients
Ready for comprehensive sync and performance testing
logs.author: CPerezz & Bloatnet Team

logs.title: Bloatnet Website Preview Released
logs.description: CPerezz created and shared the official Bloatnet Initiative website preview for community feedback and traction.
details: Website deployed at cperezz.github.io/bloatnet-website
Includes findings section for documenting discoveries
Features metrics dashboards and progress tracking
Designed to encourage collaboration and metric submissions
logs.author: CPerezz

logs.title: Infinite Healing Bug Discovered
logs.description: Critical discovery that Nethermind's healing phase gets stuck indefinitely under heavy load, preventing successful sync completion.
details: Node stuck in StateNodes sync phase for 12+ hours at 800Mgas blocks
Constantly switching between 'FastSync, StateNodes' and 'StateNodes'
Healing completed successfully in 6 minutes after reducing load
Confirms healing breaks when state changes between blocks are too numerous
logs.author: Kamil Chodoła & Ben Adams

logs.title: Major Consensus Split Event
logs.description: Network experienced two major forks: first between Besu and other clients due to ModExp gas pricing, then between Nethermind/Reth and Geth/Erigon.
details: First split: Besu using 500 gas for ModExp instead of 200, causing 600 gas difference
Second split: CL-related issues causing Nethermind/Reth vs Geth/Erigon fork
Transaction 0xccc3f79... exposed the gas calculation discrepancy
Resolved by correcting Besu to use performance branch instead of performance-modexp
logs.author: Pari, Matkt & Besu Team

logs.title: Erigon Performance Degradation at 1.5x State
logs.description: Erigon experiencing severe performance issues at 1.5x mainnet state size, unable to maintain sync with chain head.
details: Execution times exceeding 1 second per block
Node falling behind chain head consistently
Team investigating root cause, expected to take significant time to resolve
Highlights scalability challenges at increased state sizes
logs.author: milen (Erigon Team)

logs.title: Empty Block Production Bug
logs.description: Besu producing empty blocks despite thousands of pending transactions in mempool, caused by block building timeouts.
details: All-or-nothing behavior: either full blocks or completely empty
Timeout issues preventing transaction inclusion
Affects network throughput and bloating efficiency
Highlighted need for better timeout handling across clients
logs.author: ahamlat & Besu Team

logs.title: Comprehensive Testing Strategy Defined
logs.description: Marius van der Wijden outlined the complete testing roadmap for Bloatnet, establishing clear priorities and targets.
details: Priority 1: 100M gas limit at 2x mainnet state size
Create benchmarks/testcases on 2x fork for consistent metrics
Continue bloating to 4x, 6x, 8x, and 10x mainnet sizes
Investigate degenerated test cases (broad vs deep trie, accounts vs storage)
Focus on realistic scenarios: reorg + compaction + high gas blocks
logs.author: MariusVanDerWijden

logs.title: Initial Metrics Requirements Document
logs.description: CPerezz published first comprehensive metrics requirements document for all EL clients to standardize data collection.
details: Document at hackmd.io/ob66NuW9QBORHLz7emhSCw
Requested all client teams to contribute ideas
Established need for granular metrics collection
Focus on sync performance and database operations
logs.author: CPerezz

logs.title: Sync and Compaction Metrics Agreement
logs.description: Teams reached consensus on standardized metrics collection following major reorg event, establishing unified measurement standards.
details: Metrics document at hackmd.io/@CPerezz/SkzDZmngT
Agreement reached after 1600+ block reorg incident
Defined healing phase duration tracking
Established I/O performance measurement standards
Consensus on using node exporter for cross-client compatibility
logs.author: CPerezz & Client Teams

logs.title: Client Implementation Deep-Dive Questionnaire
logs.description: Comprehensive questionnaire released to gather detailed implementation specifics from each client team for creating targeted test scenarios.
details: Document at hackmd.io/@CPerezz/HkZlj_jIgg
Questions covering client-specific tradeoffs and optimizations
Designed to inform EELS test case creation
Geth and Besu completed questionnaires promptly
Pending responses from Nethermind, Erigon, and Reth
logs.author: CPerezz

logs.title: Comprehensive Test Scenarios Catalog Released
logs.description: Published extensive catalog of all planned test scenarios for BloatNet, open for community review and contributions.
details: Document at hackmd.io/@CPerezz/ryoMhzaLel
Includes state bloating scenarios
Attack vector test cases
Performance stress tests
Open for expert opinions and improvements from all teams
logs.author: CPerezz

logs.title: First Round Sync Test Results & Critical Findings
logs.description: Completed first comprehensive sync test round across all clients at 1.5x mainnet state, revealing critical issues and performance bottlenecks requiring immediate fixes.
details: Nethermind: Healing phase stuck indefinitely at 800Mgas blocks, required load reduction to 300Mgas for completion
Besu: Chain ID confusion causing mainnet peering instead of testnet, snap sync struggling significantly
Reth: Memory capacity errors during serialization, requiring investigation of state handling
Erigon: Severe performance degradation, unable to keep up with chain head at 1.5x state
Geth: Most stable performance but experiencing memory issues with 128 trie layers
Syncoor dashboard deployed at syncoor.perf-devnet-2.ethpandaops.io for monitoring
Critical finding: Healing phase breaks when state changes between blocks exceed client capacity
Action items: Reduce gas limit from 800M to 300M, implement better timeout handling, fix chainID issues
logs.author: Syncoor Team & Client Teams

logs.title: 2x Mainnet State Sync Testing - Critical Peering Issues Block Progress
logs.description: Reached 2x mainnet state size and attempted comprehensive sync testing, but severe peering issues prevented most clients from completing sync due to mainnet peer confusion on shadowfork network.
details: State reached 2x mainnet size with balanced distribution across accounts, contracts, and storage
Perf-devnet-2 network deployed with syncoor dashboard at syncoor.perf-devnet-2.ethpandaops.io
Critical shadowfork peering issues discovered:
- All nodes filling up with mainnet peers due to identical forkID
- No available peer slots for sync test machines to connect
- Required manual admin API intervention to add peers
Sync test results at 2x state:
- Geth: Successfully synced after adding --eth.requiredblocks flag to filter mainnet peers
- Besu: Successfully synced after using --required-block flag for peer filtering
- Nethermind: Unable to complete sync tests, missing requiredblocks feature for peer filtering
- Reth: 0 EL peers, unable to sync without requiredblocks flag or constant peer management
- Erigon: Unable to sync, awaiting clarification on shadowfork.block env variable
Key finding: Shadowfork networks need unique forkID or salt to prevent mainnet peer confusion
Proposed solutions: Add requiredblocks flag to all clients or implement network ID salt
Decision to pause sync testing until peering issues resolved across all clients
logs.author: Syncoor Team & DevOps

logs.title: EEST Stubbed Contracts Support for Stateful Testing
logs.description: Mario Vega (marioevz) from EELS team implemented stubbed contracts support in EEST, enabling stateful tests to query existing contracts in state for benchmarking scenarios like XEN tests.
details: PR merged: https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/pull/2073
Enables implementation of XEN tests and other stateful scenarios
Reviewed by CPerezz and Felipe who identified JSON string input parsing error
PR merged after fixing the identified parsing issue
Critical feature for creating realistic state-dependent benchmarks
logs.author: Mario Vega (EELS Team)

logs.title: Single-Opcode State Access Tests for Bloatnet
logs.description: Guillaume Ballet from Stateless & Geth teams submitted first PR implementing single-opcode tests for state access operations, starting with SSTORE and SLOAD support.
details: PR submitted: https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/pull/2040
Initial implementation covers SSTORE and SLOAD opcodes
Part of comprehensive opcode-level testing strategy for Bloatnet
Enables granular performance analysis of state access operations
Foundation for expanded opcode coverage in future PRs
logs.author: gballet (Stateless & Geth Teams)

logs.title: Cold BALANCE + Warm EXTCODESIZE Scenario for Spamoor
logs.description: Han submitted PR implementing Cold BALANCE + Warm EXTCODESIZE attack scenario for spamoor, targeting specific gas cost vulnerabilities in state access patterns.
details: PR submitted for review: https://github.com/ethpandaops/spamoor/pull/124
Implements cold BALANCE opcode calls combined with warm EXTCODESIZE operations
Targets gas cost asymmetries in state access patterns
Awaiting review from CPerezz before merge
Adds to comprehensive suite of state bloating attack vectors
logs.author: Han

logs.title: Multiple Clients Implementing Shadowfork Peering Fix
logs.description: Erigon and Reth teams actively implementing --eth.requiredblock flag to resolve shadowfork peering issues, while Nethermind has opened tracking issue awaiting implementer assignment.
details: Initial concern: shadowforks need mainnet peers for transaction forwarding
Pari clarified mempool bridge tool handles mainnet tx rebroadcasting without p2p peering
Key insight: chainId in transaction RLP and signatures prevents simple network separation
Erigon: Milen confirmed implementation, expected within days after current tasks
Reth: Active implementation in progress - https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/issues/18062
Nethermind: Issue opened, awaiting implementer - https://github.com/NethermindEth/nethermind/issues/9204
Geth and Besu already have this functionality
This will unblock sync testing for all clients at 2x mainnet state
logs.author: Erigon, Reth & Nethermind Teams

logs.title: Nethermind Sync Testing with Pivot Flags Solution
logs.description: Nethermind team successfully initiated sync testing at 2x mainnet state using specific pivot flags, discovering that --eth.requiredblock flag is no longer required for shadowfork sync.
details: Initial sync attempts failed after 68+ hours without proper peer discovery
Kamil Chodoła and Łukasz Rozmej provided solution with pivot flags:
- Added specific pivot hash and number for sync targeting
- Set Sync.PivotHash=0x77811bb477a5d40cc40b694fa7e6a3482772f2d045a91f725fe40b9215ef51b2
- Set Sync.PivotNumber=23142646 and Sync.PivotTotalDifficulty=58750003716598352816469
- Enabled discovery and removed static peer restrictions
Initial slow progress (0.01%) improved to 5% in 10 minutes after connecting to more peers
Successfully connected to both Besu and Geth nodes for snap sync
Key finding: --eth.requiredblock flag is no longer required for Nethermind
Pivot flags provide sufficient targeting for shadowfork sync without mainnet peer confusion
GitHub Actions run: https://github.com/ethpandaops/perf-devnets/actions/runs/17321647521
logs.author: Kamil Chodoła & Nethermind Team

logs.title: Not All State Is Equal - Critical State Growth Analysis
logs.description: Han's article 'Not All State Is Equal' reveals crucial insights about state access patterns and potential attack vectors, prompting new bloating scenario development for targeting non-existent addresses.
details: Article published at: https://notes.ethereum.org/@weiihann/not-all-state-is-equal
Key finding: State access to non-existent addresses significantly cheaper than existing ones
Guillaume (Geth team) identified potential attack: deploying contracts at addresses that don't exist yet
Attack vector: Could amortize the 21000 gas transaction cost by creating factory contracts
Discussion on bloom filter implementation to mitigate, but size requirements unclear
Impact on MPT vs unified tree structures: Works for MPT but not for unified trees with code grouped with account
gballet identified new bloatnet scenario: Contract sending 1 wei to many non-existing addresses
Guillaume's concern: Could incentivize cheaper account creation via factories, leading to state bloat
Alternative attack vector suggested: Sending 1 wei to many contracts for cheaper state manipulation
Critical insight: Current gas pricing may not properly reflect actual computational costs for different state access patterns
logs.author: Han, Guillaume (Geth Team) & CPerezz

logs.title: EEST Multi-Opcode Testing Support Enabled
logs.description: CPerezz fixed a critical bug in execution-spec-tests that was blocking multi-opcode testing for Bloatnet, enabling the first multi-opcode PR to be merged.
details: PR #2193 merged to ethereum/execution-spec-tests repository
Fixed missing return statement in deploy_contract() method for stub contracts
Prevented assertion errors when using stub contracts with predefined addresses
Enables factory contract deployment patterns critical for Bloatnet testing
Example use case: factory_address = pre.deploy_contract(code=Bytecode(), stub="bloatnet_factory")
Unblocks multi-opcode testing scenarios required for comprehensive state bloat analysis
logs.author: CPerezz

logs.title: Reth Syncing Issues Investigation - Peering and Disconnect Problems
logs.description: Extended investigation into Reth client's inability to sync with the Bloatnet network revealed critical peering issues, aggressive reconnection timeouts, and disconnect problems preventing successful synchronization.
details: Reth unable to maintain stable connections to trusted peers, constantly disconnecting
Only able to connect to Geth archive node but syncs headers only to block 15555201 before disconnect
Identified aggressive reconnection timeouts causing IP throttling on remote peers
Required-block chicken-and-egg problem: needs peers to download blocks, but peers reject without required block
Geth using --eth.requiredblocks flag while Nethermind, Besu, and Reth lack this feature initially
Empty header responses from peers when required block not present causing sync failures
Matthias Seitz (Reth team) identified reconnection timeout issues as potential root cause
YK from Paradigm team requested access to node logs to debug disconnect reasons
Consistent disconnect after downloading block 15555201 suggests possible archive node limitation
Reth team using Kurtosis setup for local debugging: github.com/ethpandaops/perf-devnets/tree/master/docs/debug/reth-syncing
No ETA on fix, Bloatnet sync benchmarks proceeding without Reth temporarily
Georgios Konstantopoulos raised concerns about fragility of forkid/networkid mechanism
Rafael Matias confirmed clean runs with new node keys ruling out peer ID banning
Team granted SSH access to Paradigm engineers for direct VM debugging
logs.author: Reth Team (Matthias, YK) & EthPandaOps
